events.title: Vikings Reach North America
events.description: Vikings reached Labrador and Newfoundland, establishing a settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows (now a UNESCO World Heritage site).
events.examTip: L'Anse aux Meadows is a commonly tested fact.

events.title: John Cabot Maps Atlantic Coast
events.description: John Cabot mapped Canada's Atlantic coast, one of the first European explorations of the region.

events.title: Jacques Cartier Explores St. Lawrence
events.description: Jacques Cartier explored the St. Lawrence River for France. The name 'Canada' comes from the Iroquoian word 'kanata' meaning village.
events.examTip: The origin of the word 'Canada' is frequently tested.

events.title: Quebec City Founded
events.description: Samuel de Champlain founded Quebec City, earning him the title 'Father of New France'.

events.title: Hudson's Bay Company Established
events.description: The Hudson's Bay Company was established, becoming a major force in the fur trade and exploration of Canada's interior.

events.title: First Representative Assembly
events.description: The first representative assembly was elected in Halifax, Nova Scotia, marking the beginning of democratic governance in Canada.

events.title: Battle of the Plains of Abraham
events.description: Britain defeated France in the Battle of the Plains of Abraham, ending France's empire in America. Both generals died: British General Wolfe and French General Montcalm.
events.examTip: Both generals dying in the same battle is a key exam fact.

events.title: Quebec Act
events.description: The Quebec Act allowed Catholic freedom, French civil law, and British criminal law in Quebec.

events.title: United Empire Loyalists Arrive
events.description: Over 40,000 people loyal to the British Crown fled the American Revolution to Canada, shaping the country's English-speaking character.
events.examTip: Know that Loyalists were loyal to the Crown, not to the American revolution.

events.title: Constitutional Act
events.description: The Constitutional Act of 1791 granted Canada's first elected legislative assemblies, splitting the province into Upper Canada (Ontario) and Lower Canada (Quebec).

events.title: Upper Canada Moves to Abolish Slavery
events.description: Upper Canada (Ontario) became the first province in the British Empire to move toward abolishing slavery, led by Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe.
events.examTip: Upper Canada led the British Empire in abolition.

events.title: British Parliament Prohibits Slave Trading
events.description: The British Parliament prohibited the buying and selling of slaves throughout the Empire.

events.title: Slavery Abolished in British Empire
events.description: Slavery was abolished throughout the British Empire. The Underground Railroad, a Christian anti-slavery network, helped thousands of slaves escape to Canada.

events.title: War of 1812 Begins
events.description: The United States invaded Canada but was defeated. The Battle of Queenston Heights was a key early victory, though Major General Sir Isaac Brock died leading it.

events.title: Laura Secord's Warning
events.description: Laura Secord, a pioneer woman, walked 30 km through rough terrain to warn Lieutenant James FitzGibbon of an American attack, helping secure a Canadian victory.
events.examTip: Laura Secord's 30 km walk is a frequently tested detail.

events.title: British Forces Burn the White House
events.description: British forces, including troops from Canada, burned the White House in Washington, D.C. during the War of 1812.

events.title: Rebellions in Upper and Lower Canada
events.description: Armed rebellions in Upper and Lower Canada led to Lord Durham's Report, which recommended responsible government for the colonies.

events.title: Responsible Government Achieved
events.description: Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine became the first leader of responsible government in Canada, working alongside Robert Baldwin. La Fontaine was also a champion of French language rights.

events.title: Confederation
events.description: The British North America Act (now Constitution Act, 1867) created the Dominion of Canada with four founding provinces: Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia, and New Brunswick. July 1 was called Dominion Day until 1982, now Canada Day.
events.examTip: Know the four original provinces and that Macdonald was the first PM.

events.title: Red River Rebellion
events.description: Louis Riel led the Metis uprising at Fort Garry (now Winnipeg), establishing Manitoba as a province. He is considered the father of Manitoba.

events.title: North West Mounted Police Established
events.description: The North West Mounted Police (NWMP) was established to maintain order in the western territories. It later became the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP).

events.title: Canadian Pacific Railway Completed
events.description: The Canadian Pacific Railway was completed when Donald Smith (Lord Strathcona) drove the last spike at Craigellachie, British Columbia. A discriminatory Chinese head tax was imposed after construction (1885-1923); Canada apologized in 2006.
events.examTip: Know the date, location (Craigellachie, BC), and the Chinese head tax connection.

events.title: Sir Wilfrid Laurier Becomes PM
events.description: Sir Wilfrid Laurier became the first French-Canadian Prime Minister since Confederation. His portrait appears on the $5 bill. He encouraged massive western immigration.
events.examTip: Laurier is on the $5 bill; Macdonald is on the $10 bill.

events.title: "In Flanders Fields" Written
events.description: Lieutenant-Colonel John McCrae wrote the poem 'In Flanders Fields,' which inspired the remembrance poppy as a symbol of sacrifice.

events.title: Battle of Vimy Ridge
events.description: Canadian troops captured Vimy Ridge in a decisive victory with 10,000 casualties. The battle is often called the 'birth of a nation' for Canada. April 9 is now Vimy Day.
events.examTip: Vimy Ridge (April 9, 1917) is one of the most commonly tested dates.

events.title: World War I Ends
events.description: Over 600,000 Canadians served in World War I; approximately 60,000 died and 170,000 were wounded.

events.title: Manitoba Grants Women Voting Rights
events.description: Manitoba became the first province to grant women the right to vote. Dr. Emily Stowe had founded the women's suffrage movement in Canada.

events.title: Women Gain Federal Vote
events.description: Most women over 21 gained the right to vote in federal elections.

events.title: First Female Member of Parliament
events.description: Agnes Macphail became Canada's first female Member of Parliament.

events.title: World War II
events.description: Over one million Canadians served in World War II; 44,000 died. The Royal Canadian Navy became the world's third-largest navy by war's end.

events.title: D-Day: Juno Beach
events.description: About 15,000 Canadian troops stormed Juno Beach on D-Day, one of the pivotal moments of World War II.
events.examTip: Canadians landed at Juno Beach specifically (not Omaha or Utah).

events.title: Remembrance Day Tradition
events.description: November 11 (Remembrance Day) honours the over 110,000 Canadians who gave their lives in military service. The red poppy is worn as a symbol of remembrance.

events.title: Old Age Security Established
events.description: Old Age Security (OAS) was established as one of Canada's first major social programs.

events.title: Employment Insurance Introduced
events.description: Employment Insurance (originally Unemployment Insurance) was introduced federally, providing income support for workers between jobs.

events.title: Oil Discovered in Alberta
events.description: Oil was discovered at Leduc, Alberta, launching Canada's modern energy industry.

events.title: Newfoundland Joins Canada & NATO
events.description: Newfoundland and Labrador became the last province to join Canada. In the same year, Canada joined NATO.
events.examTip: Newfoundland and Labrador was the last province to join (1949).

events.title: Korean War
events.description: 26,000 Canadians served in the Korean War; 516 were killed and over 1,000 were wounded.

events.title: Quiet Revolution in Quebec
events.description: Quebec underwent rapid modernization during the Quiet Revolution, including secularization and modernized education and healthcare systems.

events.title: Canada/Quebec Pension Plans Created
events.description: The Canada Pension Plan (CPP) and Quebec Pension Plan (QPP) were created to provide retirement income for Canadians.

events.title: Official Languages Act
events.description: The Official Languages Act guaranteed French and English services in the federal government, reinforcing Canada's bilingual character.

events.title: Summit Series
events.description: Paul Henderson scored 'the goal heard around the world' in the Canada-Soviet Summit Series, a defining moment in Canadian sports history.

events.title: Terry Fox's Marathon of Hope
events.description: Terry Fox, a young British Columbian who lost his leg to cancer, ran his Marathon of Hope to raise money for cancer research. Quebec's first sovereignty referendum was also defeated this year.

events.title: Charter of Rights and Freedoms
events.description: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms was entrenched in the Constitution, guaranteeing fundamental rights for all Canadians.
events.examTip: The Charter (1982) is distinct from the Bill of Rights (1960).

events.title: NAFTA Takes Effect
events.description: The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) between Canada, the United States, and Mexico came into effect.

events.title: Quebec Sovereignty Referendum
events.description: Quebec's second sovereignty referendum was narrowly defeated, with 50.58% voting No.

events.title: Nunavut Becomes a Territory
events.description: Nunavut was established as Canada's newest territory, carved from the eastern part of the Northwest Territories.

events.title: Chinese Head Tax Apology
events.description: The Canadian government formally apologized for the Chinese head tax, a discriminatory entry fee imposed on Chinese immigrants from 1885 to 1923.

events.title: Residential Schools Apology
events.description: The federal government formally apologized for the residential school system, which had removed Aboriginal children from their families from the 1800s to the 1980s.

events.title: USMCA Replaces NAFTA
events.description: The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) replaced NAFTA as the trade agreement between the three countries.
